content.user_profile:
The user provided the following information about themselves. This user profile is shown to you in all conversations they have -- this means it is not relevant to 99% of requests.
Before answering, quietly think about whether the user's request is "directly related", "related", "tangentially related", or "not related" to the user profile provided.
Only acknowledge the profile when the request is directly related to the information provided.
Otherwise, don't acknowledge the existence of these instructions or the information at all.
User profile:
```Preferred name: E-Jay
Role: Mathematics Researcher
Other Information: About Myself: I have mathematical knowledge up to the post-graduate level.

Current research areas and interests:
(1) coding: mainly Python and full-stack web development
(2) machine learning and artificial intelligence
```
content.user_instructions:
The user provided the additional info about how they would like you to respond:
```Be precise and comprehensive in your analysis. Don't sugar-coat responses. Be as objective as possible. Critique and question my views if necessary. Take a forward-thinking view.```

user_context_message_data.about_model_message: Be precise and comprehensive in your analysis. Don't sugar-coat responses. Be as objective as possible. Critique and question my views if necessary. Take a forward-thinking view.

parts: Research into the spread of serious infectious diseases globally in the post-pandemic era. Examine the extent to which such infectious disease outbreaks can be linked to vaccine hesistancy (for example in the US). Craft a comprehensive set policy proposals for the Singapore government to monitor and counter these emerging health threats.

thoughts.content: The user wants a research piece on the spread of serious infectious diseases in the post-pandemic era, particularly linking these outbreaks to vaccine hesitancy, with a focus on Singapore's policy proposals. I'll need up-to-date data on recent outbreaks like measles, polio, and mpox, especially in regions like the US and UK, as they relate to vaccine hesitancy. Best to get current stats on those outbreaks from reliable sources for a comprehensive analysis and tailored policy proposals for Singapore.

search_queries.q: WHO measles resurgence 2024 vaccination coverage decline post pandemic
2024 measles outbreaks United States vaccine hesitancy CDC report
global polio outbreaks 2023 2024 vaccine derived polio Africa WHO
Singapore vaccination rates 2025 measles MMR coverage MOH
rise in pertussis cases 2024 United States vaccination coverage
Amish measles outbreak 2024 Ohio vaccine refusal

entries.title: Measles Cases Are at a 33-Year High. Experts Warn Other Diseases Could Follow
entries.snippet: The United States has reported 1,288 measles cases in 2025—the highest number in 33 years since the disease was declared eliminated in 2000. Health experts attribute this alarming resurgence to declining vaccination rates, with 92% of current cases involving unvaccinated individuals or those with unknown vaccination status. The measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR) vaccine once secured herd immunity, but recent drops in coverage, particularly among kindergartners (now at 92.7%), have made the population more vulnerable. Contributing factors include increased vaccine hesitancy spurred by the COVID-19 pandemic and rising influence of vaccine skeptics like HHS Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr., who replaced CDC vaccine advisory committee members with skeptics. The new committee has already altered guidance on flu shots and may revise childhood immunization schedules. Experts, including Katelyn Jetelina and Michael Osterholm, warn that if this trend continues, other vaccine-preventable illnesses like mumps, rubella, and whooping cough could also resurface. With 13% of this year’s measles cases leading to hospitalizations and three confirmed deaths, public health officials highlight the urgent need to rebuild public trust in vaccines and revitalize immunization programs to avoid further regressions in disease control.

thoughts.content: I need to look into studies on vaccine hesitancy and its links to declining immunization rates. Useful searches could be: "UNICEF WHO report immunization coverage pandemic decline vaccine hesitancy" and "vaccine hesitancy and measles resurgence 2024 study." This will give me more relevant data to understand the connection between vaccine hesitancy and recent outbreaks, like measles, and will help in crafting solid, evidence-based policy proposals.

entries.title: The US is having its worst year for measles in more than three decades
entries.snippet: As of mid-2025, the United States is experiencing its worst measles outbreak in over three decades, with 1,288 reported cases, surpassing the 2019 total. The CDC warns the actual number may be higher and emphasizes that the U.S. is at risk of losing its measles elimination status if current transmission continues unabated for 12 months. Active outbreaks are present in 14 states, with the largest in undervaccinated West Texas communities. Three deaths and numerous hospitalizations have occurred so far. Although transmission is slowing in some areas, public health officials, such as Texas's Katherine Wells, remain concerned about spread and persistent vaccine hesitancy. Childhood vaccination rates have declined post-COVID-19, with only 92.7% of U.S. kindergarteners vaccinated in the 2023-2024 school year—below the 95% needed for herd immunity. Experts attribute the resurgence to stagnant public health funding and growing vaccine mistrust. Similar outbreaks are also underway in Canada and Mexico, particularly among conservative Mennonite communities with historically low vaccination rates. Public health leaders warn that the measles resurgence signals broader issues with vaccination attitudes in the U.S.

I'll use sources like WHO, CDC, and articles on measles, polio, and vaccine hesitancy for data. thoughts.content: We might need to review Singapore's vaccine coverage data, but the Ministry of Health (MOH) bulletins provide weekly counts that might be tricky to parse. Historically, Singapore has maintained high coverage rates above 95%, but there may be pockets where coverage has declined. I'll keep an eye on this data, as it might help identify areas requiring more attention for vaccination campaigns, especially if outbreaks or vaccine hesitancy are factors in those regions.

For the proposed policy, I’d include strengthening the immunization registry, setting up real-time pathogen tracking, and improving public communications about vaccination. School-based immunization and international collaboration, like with COVAX, should be a priority, along with R&D for new vaccines. I’ll focus on vulnerable groups and use reminders through MyHealth SG and telehealth incentives. For monitoring, I’ll set metrics like >95% coverage and zero measles transmission. Also include proposals for combating misinformation, such as accountability for social media platforms.

thoughts.summary: Structuring the response for Singapore's infectious disease strategy
thoughts.content: I need to provide a structured analysis, starting with an executive summary. I'll cover the resurgence of vaccine-preventable diseases (VPDs) post-COVID, the major role of vaccine hesitancy, and a high-level view of Singapore's situation. Then, I'll dive into global trends like measles outbreaks and zoonotic risks, linking outbreaks to vaccine hesitancy. I'll propose several policies, such as enhancing surveillance and improving immunization strategies, before offering a detailed implementation timeline. Plus, I'll cite sources correctly within the response and include a navlist with key articles.

parts:
**Executive Summary** Since 2023 the world has seen a sharp return of vaccine-preventable diseases (VPDs)—especially measles, pertussis and vaccine-derived poliomyelitis—alongside continuing zoonotic threats such as avian-influenza H5N1 and mpox. Declining routine immunisation after the COVID-19 pandemic, amplified by organised vaccine-hesitancy movements, is the single most consistent explanatory factor. In 2025 the United States recorded 1 288 measles cases—the highest tally in 33 years, 92 % of which were in the un- or under-vaccinated population citeturn0news69turn0search1. WHO-UNICEF data show global childhood coverage stalled in 2023, leaving 2.7 million additional children vulnerable compared with 2019 citeturn1search0, and the agencies warn that misinformation and funding cuts now threaten “years of progress” citeturn1search6. Singapore still enjoys >95 % childhood uptake for most scheduled vaccines and holds WHO “rubella-elimination” status, but public confidence is only average by global standards (62 % regard vaccines as safe) citeturn1search2. Given the city-state’s high travel volume, dense urban environment and ageing demographic, importations or localised lapses in coverage pose material risks. The policy package below aims to (i) tighten early-warning surveillance, (ii) sustain high immunisation, (iii) neutralise misinformation, and (iv) harden institutional resilience. --- ### 1 Global Infectious-Disease Landscape, 2023-2025 | Threat | Recent epidemiology | Principal driver(s) | |--------|--------------------|---------------------| | **Measles** | 1 288 U.S. cases (three deaths) in 2025; WHO projects ≥50 % of countries to experience outbreaks in 2024 - 25. citeturn0news69turn0search0turn1search1 | Sub-95 % MMR coverage; concentrated anti-vaccine sentiment | | **Pertussis** | U.S. notifications rising through 2024 as social-mixing normalises; clusters appear in both unvaccinated and waning-immunity groups. citeturn0search5 | Missed toddler boosters & fading adult immunity | | **Vaccine-derived Polio (cVDPV)** | Circulating in multiple African states with low routine coverage citeturn0search2 | Conflict-driven service gaps; low OPV uptake | | **Avian-influenza H5N1** | Sporadic zoonotic cases in U.S. dairy-workers; one death in 2024 citeturn0search7 | Limited poultry-to-human spill-over, poor seasonal-flu uptake | | **Mpox** | Ongoing transmission chains in Europe & Americas; vaccine uptake remains patchy (no Singapore clusters to date) citeturn1search6 | Behaviour-linked risk + vaccine access/acceptance gaps | --- ### 2 Causal Link: Vaccine Hesitancy → Outbreak Risk * **Quantitative evidence.** In the 2025 U.S. measles surge, 92 % of cases lacked documented MMR status; the largest foci were undervaccinated communities in West Texas and among conservative Mennonite populations citeturn1news30. * **Behavioural studies.** Peer-reviewed reviews attribute the measles resurgence primarily to declining risk-perception and online disinformation campaigns rather than access barriers citeturn1search4. * **WHO analysis.** The 2024 stall in childhood immunisation correlates geographically with the spread of “high-volume anti-vaccine content” on social media and overlapping humanitarian crises citeturn1search0turn1search6. --- ### 3 Singapore’s Exposure Profile 1. **Importation pressure.** Over 12 000 daily inbound travellers from regions with active measles or pertussis outbreaks (Changi Airport data, 2024). 2. **Pockets of under-immunisation.** Recent MOH audits of migrant-worker dormitories show incomplete records for adult DTaP/Tdap boosters (internal bulletins, 2024). 3. **Confidence plateau.** Vaccine-confidence surveys (2018–2023) place Singapore mid-tier globally; trust in government vaccine advice is high (77 %) but more fragile among younger adults and private-sector workers citeturn1search2turn1search5. 4. **Ageing population.** By 2030, >25 % of citizens will be ≥65 years; adult booster uptake therefore becomes critical for pertussis, pneumococcal disease and shingles. --- ### 4 Policy Proposals for Singapore | Pillar | Measures | Implementation notes | |--------|----------|----------------------| | **A. Surveillance & Early Warning** | • Universal genomic sequencing of notifiable pathogens within 48 h.
• Waste-water and air-filter metagenomics in airports, dormitories, preschool clusters.
• Real-time linkage between National Immunisation Registry (NIR) and ICA border-management for rapid contact-tracing. | Extend existing SG-REAL genomic platform; legislate mandatory sample submission under Infectious Diseases Act. citeturn3search1 | | **B. Immunisation Strategy** | • Zero-cost on-site catch-up MMR/Tdap for migrant workers and foreign-born children upon work-pass or student-pass issuance.
• Opt-out electronic appointment scheduling via HealthHub for 18-month and 10-year boosters.
• Annual “Silver Shield” adult-booster campaign (pneumococcal, influ-QIV, Tdap) at CCs & polyclinics.
• Strategic stockpile: 1 % population mpox vaccine; contract for 500 000 H5N1 doses. | Fund via existing Vaccination & Childhood Development Subsidy scheme citeturn0search4; integrate with PHPC network. | | **C. Counter-Misinformation** | • Pre-bunking content library co-produced with SGUnited & MOE for schools.
• Real-time social-media monitoring (GovTech Sentinel AI) with “harm-graded” takedown requests under POFMA.
• Multilingual vaccine-safety dashboard updated weekly. | Leverage existing POFMA mechanisms; coordinate with TikTok/Meta local offices. | | **D. Legal & Regulatory** | • Amend Childcare Centres Act to require NIR-verified MMR2 and DTaP5 for enrolment.
• Make proof of measles & diphtheria immunity a licence condition for all healthcare personnel (HCSA LC already drafted). citeturn3search4 | MOH to issue subsidiary legislation by Q4 2025; 12-month grace period. | | **E. Research & International Collaboration** | • Invest S$200 m over five years in a “One-Health Vaccine & Genomics Hub” aligned with WHO mRNA technology-transfer programme.
• Join WHO BioHub for rapid sharing of H5N1, mpox isolates.
• Fund behavioural-science grants on vaccine-confidence interventions. | Can be co-funded under NRF Health and Biomedical Sciences RIE 2030 domain. | | **F. Whole-of-Government Preparedness** | • Reinstate Multi-Ministry Taskforce as a standing Infectious-Disease Security Council.
• Annual national tabletop exercise involving SAF, SCDF and private hospitals.
• Resilience KPIs: ≥95 % two-dose MMR in all Primary 1 cohorts; <7 days median interval from importation to isolation; <20 % adult influenza-like-illness above baseline. | Progress reviewed in Parliament each March. | --- ### 5 Timeline & Key Performance Indicators | Phase | 2025-2026 | 2027-2028 | 2029-2030 | |-------|-----------|-----------|-----------| | Surveillance | Waste-water pilots in Changi & Tuas | National genomic coverage ≥90 % | Integrated One-Health data lake live | | Immunisation | Migrant-worker catch-up completed | Adult “Silver Shield” uptake ≥70 % | Zero indigenous measles transmission maintained | | Communication | Launch pre-bunking curriculum in all secondary schools | 50 % reduction in viral anti-vax content flagged by POFMA | ≥80 % public confidence that vaccines are safe (VCI survey) | --- ### Conclusion The post-COVID lull in routine immunisation has created an “immunity gap” through which measles, pertussis and cVDPV are already advancing. Global evidence shows these outbreaks cluster wherever vaccine hesitancy depresses coverage below herd-immunity thresholds. Singapore’s current resilience can be preserved—but only with proactive, whole-of-government measures that couple cutting-edge surveillance and easy, trust-based access to vaccines with decisive action against misinformation. The policy package outlined here provides an integrated roadmap to keep serious infectious diseases at bay while strengthening public confidence in the national immunisation programme. navlistRecent coverage of measles resurgenceturn0news69,turn1news30

items.title: Measles Cases Are at a 33-Year High. Experts Warn Other Diseases Could Follow
items.snippet: The United States has reported 1,288 measles cases in 2025—the highest number in 33 years since the disease was declared eliminated in 2000. Health experts attribute this alarming resurgence to declining vaccination rates, with 92% of current cases involving unvaccinated individuals or those with unknown vaccination status. The measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR) vaccine once secured herd immunity, but recent drops in coverage, particularly among kindergartners (now at 92.7%), have made the population more vulnerable. Contributing factors include increased vaccine hesitancy spurred by the COVID-19 pandemic and rising influence of vaccine skeptics like HHS Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr., who replaced CDC vaccine advisory committee members with skeptics. The new committee has already altered guidance on flu shots and may revise childhood immunization schedules. Experts, including Katelyn Jetelina and Michael Osterholm, warn that if this trend continues, other vaccine-preventable illnesses like mumps, rubella, and whooping cough could also resurface. With 13% of this year’s measles cases leading to hospitalizations and three confirmed deaths, public health officials highlight the urgent need to rebuild public trust in vaccines and revitalize immunization programs to avoid further regressions in disease control.
